awd_titl_txt: Group Identification Under Stress: A Comparative Study
awd_abstract_narration:
This study investigates how one localized segment of an advantaged group understands its position in the societal context in an era in which general views of that position may be changing.  Theory and past research suggest that people’s ideas are influenced by the major social, political, and economic events through which they live, and that people’s sense-making tends to vary by region and locality.  In this research, members of the target group are interviewed to investigate their understandings of their position and their associated thought processes.  Findings from this project will help to develop a more nuanced view of the regional group studied, and in particular will aid those designing practices to mitigate undesirable effects of differences in opportunities.  Honors undergraduate students will assist in data collection, helping to build the methodological skills of the next generation of scientists.

Data for this project come from in-depth interviews of 150 members of the advantaged group, divided between two locations: one moderately sized city and one town.  Sampling follows a purposive design to maximize the range of interviewees’ contexts and relevant experiences.  Data are analyzed using flexible coding and standard software for analyzing interview and qualitative data.  This project is jointly funded by the Sociology Program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With generous support from the National Science Foundation, I was able to hire, teach, and train a total of five graduate students in how to design social research, how to conduct in-depth qualitative interviews, how to code that interview data, and how to prepare that data for dissemination.

I want to stress that because I work in a department with only an MA-granting graduate degree program, all five students were or are Masters students. Yet, we were incredibly successful, as I’ll describe below.

In addition to teaching and training graduate students, funding from this project allowed me to align one of my undergraduate seminars and the students enrolled in it with my team’s research efforts. Those undergraduate students – around 12 total – were also trained in how to design social research, and allowed to accompany my graduate student team members on several interviews. Some, after preparation, were even allowed to serve as ‘second interviewers’, giving them hands-on research experiences as undergraduate students.

Funding for this project allowed us to make significant intellectual contributions to the sociological understanding of the relationship between race and region; how a person’s racial identity is tied, concretely, to the kinds of places where they live, work, and get along in life. We presented four papers across two separate conferences from this project. We published one manuscript from this project in the very highly regarded journal, Social Problems. Funding from this award allowed us to publish this article open-access, so that anyone can read and make use of our research. We have a second manuscript that has been accepted for publication in an edited volume, forthcoming with Polity Press, an academic publishing company based in the UK.

I want to stress that these publications involved MA-level students. The first publication, in Social Problems, includes four of those graduate students as co-authors. For MA-level students, this is unprecedented. The second publication includes two of those graduate students as co-authors. So, in sum, four of the graduate students funded through this project have one publication of record; two of the graduate students have two publications of record.

Finally, the broader impacts from this project are directly connected to its intellectual impact. A major aim of this project was to provide greater access and opportunities for underrepresented students into STEM fields and career pathways. All five graduate students aligned with this project are women. Two of the five women are members of minoritized groups. Three of the five women are first-generation college students. All five of these women have now had opportunities to present this work at professional conferences they otherwise may not have been able to attend; and four of the five students have had the opportunity to learn how to prepare this work for publication, including earning co-authorship.

I am incredibly thankful for the generous support the National Science Foundation has provided me for this research. And, it’s not done! Already, I am planning the next phases of this research project, envisioning how to expand upon it and include even more students as research partners and collaborators.
